questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Thessalonians 1:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the phrases about God's righteous judgment and the Lord's return.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'righteous judgment' (v. 7) which emphasizes God's justice
Pay attention to the contrast between those who afflict and those who are afflicted (v. 6)
Note the emotional tone of hope in the midst of suffering (v. 4)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is being judged by God, WHAT happens as a result of their actions, WHERE this judgment occurs (in terms of the spiritual realm), and WHY Paul writes about it for the Thessalonians.
tips: Include the Thessalonians' steadfast faith and growing love
Note the righteous judgment that God applies to those who do not know God and do not obey the gospel
Mention the coming revelation of the Lord with angels to execute judgment

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the righteous judgment (v. 7), the Lord's return with angels (v. 7-8), or the hope of being glorified in His saints (v. 10)?
tips: The phrase 'God considers it just to repay with affliction those who afflict them' (v. 6) shows God's justice and comfort for believers
The promise that believers will be 'glorified in His saints' and 'marveled at' (v. 10) offers hope in the midst of persecution
The contrast between eternal destruction for the ungodly and glory for the righteous (v. 9-10) highlights the stakes of the coming judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Thessalonica through this passage?
tips: Paul is affirming that the Thessalonians' faith and love are growing despite persecution, which is evidence of God's righteous judgment
He is assuring them that God will judge the wicked and provide relief for the afflicted, including the church and Paul himself
This passage connects the Thessalonians' current suffering to the coming return of Christ and the final judgment

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'righteous judgment' in this context, the timing of the Lord's return, or the distinction between the righteous and unrighteous?
tips: 'Righteous judgment' (v. 7) refers to God's just punishment of the wicked, not a general punishment but specifically for those who do not know God and do not obey the gospel
The 'coming day' of the Lord's return (v. 7) is a future event, not to be confused with the present suffering of the church
The phrase 'eternal destruction' (v. 9) is a severe consequence for the ungodly, but the passage emphasizes that believers are being prepared for glory

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's righteous judgment to your life this week? Consider the Thessalonians' example of growing faith despite persecution.
tips: Reflect on a situation where you have been persecuted or judged by others and how God's righteous judgment (as a protective force) has been active in your life
Pray for the courage to stand firm in your faith when facing opposition, knowing that God is just and will ultimately vindicate the righteous
Share the hope of Christ's return with someone who is suffering

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's righteous judgment and the hope of Christ's return.
tips: Thank God for His righteous judgment that protects believers and brings relief to the afflicted
Ask for the strength to endure persecution with faith, knowing that God is just and will reward the faithful
Pray for the Thessalonians and the church today, that they may be made worthy of the kingdom through Christ's return

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Thessalonians 2:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'the man of lawlessness' (v.3), the repetition of 'he will be revealed' (v.3, v.7), and the contrast between 'the day of the Lord' and the 'rebellion' (v.3).
tips: Notice the phrase 'the man of lawlessness' appears three times in this chapter (v.3, v.7, v.12) and is the central term
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Paul's warning: urgent but hopeful, as he emphasizes God's sovereignty
The repeated phrase 'he will be revealed' (v.3 and v.7) shows the certainty of this event

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is warned (the church in Thessalonica), WHAT is happening (the rebellion and the man of lawlessness), WHERE it is happening (the temple of God), and WHY Paul is writing (to prevent false alarms about the day of the Lord).
tips: Include the key event: the man of lawlessness opposing and exalting himself against all gods (v.4)
Note that Paul mentions the 'rebellion' coming first (v.3) and the 'mystery of lawlessness' (v.6) that is already at work
Paul's purpose is to reassure the church that the day of the Lord has not come yet, but the man of lawlessness will be revealed and destroyed

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of the man of lawlessness (v.3-4), the phrase 'the Lord Jesus will kill with the breath of His mouth' (v.7), or the concept of 'strong delusion' (v.10).
tips: The phrase 'the son of destruction' (v.3) is a powerful image of the coming antichrist, showing his destructive nature
The idea that the Lord Jesus will 'kill' the man of lawlessness with 'the breath of His mouth' (v.7) emphasizes God's sovereign power and the finality of Christ's victory
The concept of 'strong delusion' (v.10) reveals God's active role in deceiving those who reject the truth, which can resonate with modern struggles with false teachings

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Thessalonica through this passage?
tips: Paul's primary goal is to prevent false expectations about the day of the Lord and to reassure the church that God's plan is unfolding in the midst of opposition
He emphasizes that the church is chosen as the firstfruits (v.13) and that they must hold fast to the traditions they were taught
The theological significance is that Christ's return is not yet here, but the man of lawlessness (antichrist) will be destroyed by Christ, ensuring the church's safety

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The identity of the man of lawlessness, the timing of the day of the Lord, and the concept of 'strong delusion'.
tips: The term 'man of lawlessness' (v.3) is a specific term for the antichrist, but its exact identity is debated; in this context, it refers to a future figure who opposes God
The phrase 'the day of the Lord' (v.1) is not yet here, but the man of lawlessness will come first (v.3), which can be confusing because some might think the day of the Lord is imminent
The concept of 'strong delusion' (v.10) refers to God's active deception to lead people away from truth, which is a challenging theological idea because it seems to contradict God's goodness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The church must hold fast to the traditions they were taught (v.15) and not be shaken by false teachings. What specific tradition or teaching from this passage can you hold onto this week?
tips: Consider how you can share the truth about the man of lawlessness with others without causing fear
Practice being alert to false teachings in your community, as Paul warns about deception (v.10)
Commit to praying for the church to be protected from the strong delusion (v.10) and to stay focused on God's chosen people

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the truth that the church is chosen as firstfruits (v.13), and ask for protection from the man of lawlessness.
tips: Thank God for the promise that Christ will destroy the man of lawlessness with His breath (v.7)
Pray for wisdom to recognize false teachings and to hold fast to the truth
Ask God to strengthen your faith so that you are not deceived by the strong delusion (v.10)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Thessalonians 3:1-15 aloud, focusing on the phrase 'not willing to work, let him not eat' (v.10) and the contrast between idleness and work.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'not willing to work' (v.10) appears in the command
Pay attention to the example of the Thessalonians who worked (v.8)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Thessalonian church) is being warned, WHAT (to avoid idleness), WHERE (the church community), and WHY (to maintain the example of work and avoid burdening others).
tips: Include the example of the Thessalonians who worked (v.8)
Note the command: 'If anyone is not willing to work, let him not eat' (v.10)
Describe the consequence: the idler should be warned and not be a burden

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the example of the Thessalonians who worked (v.8), the command 'not willing to work, let him not eat' (v.10), or the warning to the idler (v.11-12)?
tips: The phrase 'they worked night and day' (v.8) shows the depth of commitment
The command 'If anyone is not willing to work, let him not eat' (v.10) is a strong statement of self-sufficiency
The example of the Thessalonians working without being idle (v.8) is a powerful contrast

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the Thessalonian church about idleness and work?
tips: Paul emphasizes that the church should be a community of workers who support one another through labor
The main point is that idleness (without work) is a sign of spiritual disconnection and a burden to the church
Paul's intention is to maintain the standard of Christian living that the Thessalonians had previously demonstrated

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The phrase 'not willing to work, let him not eat' (v.10)? Why is idleness a problem? The command to 'take note of that person' (v.13)?
tips: The phrase 'not willing to work, let him not eat' is a practical command for self-sufficiency, not a moral condemnation
In the context of the early church, idleness could be a sign of spiritual neglect or lack of community involvement
The command to 'take note of that person' (v.13) is a call for pastoral care without exclusion

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of work and self-sufficiency in your current situation?
tips: Identify one area where you are becoming idle (e.g., procrastination, lack of engagement)
Commit to a specific task that you can complete without burdening others
Consider how you can work to support your community without being a burden

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the church in Thessalonica and for your own life regarding idleness and work.
tips: Thank God for providing the example of work in the church
Pray for strength to avoid idleness and to be self-sufficient
Ask God to help you be a productive member of your community
